title: Change in kinetic energy of box on vertical spring

content.question: A vertical spring has unstretched length <math alttext="L sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A block is attached to the top of the spring and slowly lowered until it is at rest and the spring has length <math alttext="L sub e q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>eq</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is then pushed down until the spring is compressed to length <math alttext="L sub compressed" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>comp</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and then released. After release, at what height will the kinetic energy of the block be maximum?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction with numerator, open parenthesis, L sub equilibrium, plus L sub compressed, and denominator 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>eq</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>comp</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
